column4: HELP Please: I am running 10.10-64bit and I installed Python 2.7 from source on the Python home page. And now I am having all kinds of things not work, is there any way for me  to uninstall python 2.7 and point everything back to python 2.6.5 (thats still installed)
dummy, the easy way is to remove the entire python2.7 structure but first do this "file /usr/bin/python"
doing now
it said : /usr/bin/python: symbolic link to `/etc/alternatives/python'
now "file /etc/alternatives/python"
it said: " /etc/alternatives/python: symbolic link to `/usr/lib/python2.6' "
mmm that can't be right. My /usr/bin/python points directly to /usr/bin/python2.6
yet if i type "python" it brings me to 2.7 & many pyGTK apps stopped working (PlayOnLInux, Screenlets, etc.)

so I tried reinstalling pyGTK from source and now I can not get to the software center or update packages I get a error: " Failed to execute child process "/usr/bin/software-center" (Permission denied) "
did you install python 2.7 or pyGTK from source? Or both? The original is still 2.6.5 right?

I installed both from source first 2.7 then many apps were nto working sending me pygtk errors and such so I installed gyGTK from source (latest) and now I can not get to software center, about gnome and a few other things.  And yes python 2.6.5 is still intact did not uninstall it
where is the folder with the source code? Perhaps you can go into it and do "sudo make uninstall"
they are both on my desktop. so try sudo make uninstall?
yes, get inside pyGTK 2.7 first and then Python 2.7
that is, going backwards
okay doing now
it seemed to work fine on pyGTK doing python 2.7 now
Okay, I guess it takes some to compile and install eh? I've never done it myself. It's bad to try to upgrade Python, which is a critical component of the system.

does ntot ake to long for pyGTK i was reading over everything making sure nothing carzy happend. & when I tried to uninstall python 2.7 I got: "  make: *** No rule to make target `uninstall'.  Stop. "
not take*
mmm... did you follow a guide to install Python, or just downloaded from python.org and hit make
did the standered "./configure; make; sudo make instal"l (not all in one line though)
usually the is a make uninstall.  Well. Okay, so "python -V"  gives 2.7?
Python 2.7
perhaps removing the symlink "sudo rm /usr/bin/python"
Okay i got no errors so I am assuming it worked. What next?
perhaps recreating the simlink to python 2.6 like "sudo ln -s /usr/bin/python2.6 /usr/bin/python"
Okay it went through error free
of course, those removing recreating didn't do much.  Now just "python -V" should give you the previous 2.6.5
damn it still says "Python 2.7"
you are running this in the terminal, or idle or something?
file /usr/bin/python    "file /usr/bin/python2.6"      "file /usr/bin/python2.7"
lol yes in the standered terminal
type "which python"   and  "echo $PATH"

/usr/bin/python: symbolic link to `/usr/bin/python2.6'                               "/usr/bin/python2.6: ELF 64-bit LSB executable, x86-64, version 1 (SYSV), dynamically linked (uses shared libs), for GNU/Linux 2.6.15, stripped"                              ""/usr/bin/python2.7: ERROR: cannot open `/usr/bin/python2.7' (No such file or directory)"
"/usr/local/bin/python
okay now "file /usr/local/bin/python"
it says:   "  /usr/local/bin/python: ELF 64-bit LSB executable, x86-64, version 1 (SYSV), dynamically linked (uses shared libs), for GNU/Linux 2.6.15, not stripped "
rename that piece of cr*#/&   "sudo mv /usr/local/bin/python /usr/local/bin/python2.7" and then you should be able to "python -V" and 2.6.5
ran first command no error 2nd commanded says: "bash: /usr/local/bin/python: No such file or directory"
what?   again "which python" please
actually "which -a python" please  that lists all pythons found in the PATH
which -a python returned: "/usr/bin/python"
so please run "python -V"
it says: "bash: /usr/local/bin/python: No such file or directory"
noooooooo, why??? I don't get it.
just a though why shouldn't't I just reinstall;l python 2.6.5 *pyGTK through package manager?
can you access the package manager now?
yes
just tried yet I do not know if it will let me install them yet though
I feel there is something missing. There is no other python in your path, but when you can from the terminal, it still behaves weird.
if I type "locate /bin/python" i get "/usr/bin/python
perhaps try "sudo rm /etc/alternatives/python" which was a result earlier.  And then again "python -V"
if you want to use locate, use "sudo updatedb" and then "locate python"
python -V returned: "Python 2.6.6"  =D
after or before "rm /etc/alternatives/python"
after
so. We are good, I guess. Are your programs messed up?
let me chack
well it let me open ubuntu software center let me chack to see if it will install
everything seems to be working I just have to test to Updates and then it will be fixed =D
everything seems to be working great thank you
according to my logs, you own me money!!!
if I may ask though, how did we fix it? There was someone on the forums that had the same issue as myself and I would like to post how to fix it, or I can link you
put it on my tab =D

I recall in the programming subforum, there may be a guide somewhere buried there, explaining how to setup different versions of Python without borking your system. Basically, we removed the "links", so the original python takes precedence.
ah okay thanks

It is probable that you need to do something like "./configure --prefix=/usr/local  --suffix=2.7" or something, before compiling and installing. That should give you a separate python, under a different name, so it doesn't clash with the standard python.
ah okay, later I will try that in a VM
here a sample http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1521813&highlight=installing+python+3
WOW thank you!
I seriously was searching for something better. I do remember one thread where it was explained, the actual configure options. That thread only says to remove symlinks which is what we did.
but then you have to reset it right
someone replied on the thread I was talking about (http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1595510) is that what we did?
YES. OMG that newbie asked a few questions on the programming subforum and he still decides to go to absolute beginner talk. OMG, some people never learn. Perhaps, when he is 16,
LOL! Which is the newb? The OP or the guy who posted?
the OP, The last guy is okay.
XD I see. I doubt he will ever fix his issue
how did you install 2.7?  "I installed it myself"    ROFL
Yeah I kinda wondered about that. I tried to save the thread by posting as much info as possible because how he described it (what little he did <.<) I knew he had the same issue as me

yes! I remember now. The trick was to use "make altinstall"   like alternative install instead of just "make install"  See here: http://www.python-forum.org/pythonforum/viewtopic.php?f=1&t=10977   First post is informative, more info in that same thread, and last post shows altinstall
does this work for other programs as well?
no, "make" is not magic, it depends on a file called "Makefile". Inspecting this file tells you about its options, but is hard to "read" or understand for newbies.
I believe that just by poking around them some times. But couldn't you just ctrl-F and look for it?

yes, although, sometimes, a "rule" such as "altinstall" could be just a fictitious rule to call other rules under the hood, so it gets complicated. But sure, inspect other Makefiles, the more you learn the better.
Ah I see, thanks for the advice.
yes, search the programming forum for altinstall. This is a thread: http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1529315&highlight=altinstall
So if i altinstall 2.7, who to i call it from the terminal?
how*
well, I'm not sure, but perhaps "python2.7"   The fact is that all should have the version in the name. Only a single link "python" provides the default,
good luck. See you. Your name makes me hungry.
lol Okay cya later
